∂ℓ∂H\frac{\partial \ell}{\partial H}∂H∂ℓ​

children.value: is the derivative of a function with respect to another function, which is tricky, so we need a work-around.

children.html: ℓ(H)=∑i=1nℓ(H(xi))\ell(H) = \sum_{i = 1}^{n}\ell(H(\mathbf{x}_i))ℓ(H)=∑i=1n​ℓ(H(xi​))
∂ℓ∂H(xi)=∂ℓ∂[H(xi)]\frac{\partial \ell}{\partial H}(\mathbf{x}_i) = \frac{\partial \ell}{\partial [H(\mathbf{x}_i)]}∂H∂ℓ​(xi​)=∂[H(xi​)]∂ℓ​

children.value: , the derivative of the loss with respect to a specific function value. Now the optimization problem becomes:

children.html: ht+1=argminh∈H∑i=1n∂ℓ∂[H(xi)]⏟rih(xi)h_{t+1} = \textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}} \sum_{i = 1}^{n} \underbrace{\frac{\partial \ell}{\partial [H(\mathbf{x}_i)]}}_{r_i} h(\mathbf x_i)ht+1​=argminh∈H​i=1∑n​ri​∂[H(xi​)]∂ℓ​​​h(xi​)

ℓ(Ht+1)=ℓ(Ht+αht+1)≈ℓ(Ht)+α<∇ℓ(Ht),ht+1>=ℓ(Ht)+α∑i=1nrih(xi)<ℓ(Ht)\begin{align} \ell(H_{t+1}) &= \ell(H_t+\alpha h_{t+1}) \\ &\approx \ell(H_t) + \alpha<\nabla \ell(H_t),h_{t+1}>\\ &= \ell(H_t) + \alpha \sum_{i = 1}^{n} r_i h(\mathbf{x}_i)\\ &< \ell(H_{t}) \end{align}ℓ(Ht+1​)​=ℓ(Ht​+αht+1​)≈ℓ(Ht​)+α<∇ℓ(Ht​),ht+1​>=ℓ(Ht​)+αi=1∑n​ri​h(xi​)<ℓ(Ht​)​​

Case study #1: Gradient Boosted Regression Tree(GBRT)

h=argminh∈H∑i=1nrih(xi) original AnyBoost formulation=argminh∈H−2∑i=1ntih(xi)Swapping in ti for −ri and multiply by constant 2=argminh∈H∑i=1nti2⏟constant−2tih(xi)+(h(xi))2⏟constantAdding constant ∑iti2+h(xi)2=argminh∈H∑i=1n(h(xi)−ti)2\begin{align} h &= \textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}} \sum_{i = 1}^{n} r_i h(\mathbf{x}_i) &&\text{ original AnyBoost formulation} \\ &= \textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}-2\sum_{i = 1}^{n} t_i h(\mathbf{x}_i) &&\text{Swapping in $t_i$ for $-r_i$ and multiply by constant 2} \\ &= \textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}} \sum_{i = 1}^{n} \underbrace{t_i^2}_{\textrm{constant}} - 2t_i h(\mathbf{x}_i) + \underbrace{(h(\mathbf{x}_i))^2}_{\textrm{constant}} &&\text{Adding constant $\sum_i t_i^2+h(\mathbf{x}_i)^2$} \\ &=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}\sum_{i = 1}^{n}(h(\mathbf{x}_i)-t_i)^2 \end{align}h​=argminh∈H​i=1∑n​ri​h(xi​)=argminh∈H​−2i=1∑n​ti​h(xi​)=argminh∈H​i=1∑n​constantti2​​​−2ti​h(xi​)+constant(h(xi​))2​​=argminh∈H​i=1∑n​(h(xi​)−ti​)2​​ original AnyBoost formulationSwapping in ti​ for −ri​ and multiply by constant 2Adding constant ∑i​ti2​+h(xi​)2​​

children.value: which is simply the error between our current prediction and the correct label, so this newly added model is just fitting the error current ensemble model has. However, it is important to keep in mind that you can use any other differentiable and convex loss function

, since we are using the exponential loss here and will get a very bad result if concentrate all our weights on noise (wrongly labeled data).
At each update step, first we compute the gradient

children.html: ri=∂ℓ∂H(xi)=−yie−yiH(xi)r_i=\frac{\partial \ell}{\partial H(\mathbf{x}_i)}=-y_i {e^{-y_i H(\mathbf{x}_i)}}ri​=∂H(xi​)∂ℓ​=−yi​e−yi​H(xi​)
wi=1Ze−yiH(xi)w_i= \frac{1}{Z}e^{-y_iH(\mathbf{x}_i)}wi​=Z1​e−yi​H(xi​)
Z=∑i=1ne−yiH(xi)Z=\sum_{i=1}^{n} e^{-y_iH(\mathbf{x}_i)}Z=∑i=1n​e−yi​H(xi​)

children.value: is a normalizing factor so that

children.html: ∑i=1nwi=1.\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_i=1.∑i=1n​wi​=1.
ZZZ

children.value: is identical to the loss function. Each weight

children.html: wiw_iwi​

children.value: can now be interpreted as the relative contribution of the training point

children.html: (xi,yi)(\mathbf{x}_i,y_i)(xi​,yi​)

children.value: towards the overall loss. Therefore, at each update step, we reweight the data points according to current loss and in later part of the algorithm will prioritize those points we got really wrong.
We can translate the optimization problem of minimizing loss into a optimization probelm of minimizing the weighted classification error.

\begin{align}
h(\mathbf{x}_i)&=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}r_ih(\mathbf{x}_i)
&& \Big(\textrm{substitute in: } r_i=e^{-H(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i}\Big)\\
&=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}-\sum_{i=1}^n y_i e^{-H(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i}h(\mathbf{x}_i)
&& \Big(\textrm{substitute in: } w_i=\frac{1}{Z}e^{-H(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i}, \textrm{Z is constant}\Big)\\
&=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_i y_i h(\mathbf{x}_i)
&& \Big(y_ih(\mathbf{x}_i)\in \{+1,-1\} \textrm{ with } h(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i=1 \iff h(\mathbf{x}_i)=y_i \Big)\\
&=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}\sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)\neq y_i} w_i - \sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)= y_i} w_i
&& \Big(\sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)= y_i} w_i + \sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)\neq y_i} w_i= 1\Big)\\
&=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}\sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)\neq y_i} w_i
&& \Big(\textrm{This is the weighted classification error.}\Big)
\end{align}
children.html: h(xi)=argminh∈H∑i=1nrih(xi)(substitute in: ri=e−H(xi)yi)=argminh∈H−∑i=1nyie−H(xi)yih(xi)(substitute in: wi=1Ze−H(xi)yi,Z is constant)=argminh∈H−∑i=1nwiyih(xi)(yih(xi)∈{+1,−1} with h(xi)yi=1  ⟺  h(xi)=yi)=argminh∈H∑i:h(xi)≠yiwi−∑i:h(xi)=yiwi(∑i:h(xi)=yiwi+∑i:h(xi)≠yiwi=1)=argminh∈H∑i:h(xi)≠yiwi(This is the weighted classification error.)\begin{align} h(\mathbf{x}_i)&=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}r_ih(\mathbf{x}_i) && \Big(\textrm{substitute in: } r_i=e^{-H(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i}\Big)\\ &=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}-\sum_{i=1}^n y_i e^{-H(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i}h(\mathbf{x}_i) && \Big(\textrm{substitute in: } w_i=\frac{1}{Z}e^{-H(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i}, \textrm{Z is constant}\Big)\\ &=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_i y_i h(\mathbf{x}_i) && \Big(y_ih(\mathbf{x}_i)\in \{+1,-1\} \textrm{ with } h(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i=1 \iff h(\mathbf{x}_i)=y_i \Big)\\ &=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}\sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)\neq y_i} w_i - \sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)= y_i} w_i && \Big(\sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)= y_i} w_i + \sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)\neq y_i} w_i= 1\Big)\\ &=\textrm{argmin}_{h \in \mathbb{H}}\sum_{i: h(\mathbf{x}_i)\neq y_i} w_i && \Big(\textrm{This is the weighted classification error.}\Big) \end{align}h(xi​)​=argminh∈H​i=1∑n​ri​h(xi​)=argminh∈H​−i=1∑n​yi​e−H(xi​)yi​h(xi​)=argminh∈H​−i=1∑n​wi​yi​h(xi​)=argminh∈H​i:h(xi​)=yi​∑​wi​−i:h(xi​)=yi​∑​wi​=argminh∈H​i:h(xi​)=yi​∑​wi​​​(substitute in: ri​=e−H(xi​)yi​)(substitute in: wi​=Z1​e−H(xi​)yi​,Z is constant)(yi​h(xi​)∈{+1,−1} with h(xi​)yi​=1⟺h(xi​)=yi​)(i:h(xi​)=yi​∑​wi​+i:h(xi​)=yi​∑​wi​=1)(This is the weighted classification error.)​​

children.value: Let us denote this weighted classification error as

children.html: ϵ=∑i:h(xi)yi=−1wi\epsilon=\sum_{i:h(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i=-1} w_iϵ=∑i:h(xi​)yi​=−1​wi​

children.value: weights of those wrongly classified points
. So for AdaBoost, we only need a classifier that reduces this
. It doesn’t have to do all that well, in order for the inner-product

children.html: ∑irih(xi)\sum_i r_i h(\mathbf{x}_i)∑i​ri​h(xi​)

children.value: to be negative, it just needs less than

children.html: ϵ<0.5\epsilon<0.5ϵ<0.5
α\alphaα

children.value: In the previous example, GBRT, we set the stepsize

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: to be a small constant. As it turns out, in the AdaBoost setting we can find the

children.html: ℓ\ellℓ

children.value: every time we take a “gradient” step.
If we take the derivative of loss function

children.html: ℓ\ellℓ
α\alphaα

children.value: , we will actually find out that there is a nice closed form for

children.html: α\alphaα
α=12ln⁡1−ϵϵ\alpha = \frac{1}{2}\ln \frac{1-\epsilon}{\epsilon}α=21​lnϵ1−ϵ​

children.value: It is unusual that we can find the optimal step-size in such a simple closed form. One consequence is that AdaBoost converges extremely fast.
After you take a step, i.e.

children.html: Ht+1=Ht+αhH_{t+1}=H_{t}+\alpha hHt+1​=Ht​+αh

children.value: , you need to re-compute all the weights and then re-normalize. However, if we update

children.html: www
www
wi←wie−αh(xi)yi2ϵ(1−ϵ){w}_i\leftarrow w_i\frac{e^{-\alpha h(\mathbf{x}_i)y_i}}{2\sqrt{\epsilon(1-\epsilon)}}wi​←wi​2ϵ(1−ϵ)​e−αh(xi​)yi​​

children.value: The inner loop can terminate as the error

children.html: ϵ=12\epsilon=\frac{1}{2}ϵ=21​

children.value: , and in most cases it will converge to

children.html: 12\frac{1}{2}21​

children.value: over time. In that case the latest weak learner

children.html: hhh

children.value: is only as good as a coin toss and cannot benefit the ensemble (therefore boosting terminates). Also note that if

children.html: ϵ=12\epsilon=\frac{1}{2}ϵ=21​
α\alphaα

children.value: We can in fact show that the training loss is decreasing
! Even further, we can show that after

children.html: O(log⁡(n))O(\log(n))O(log(n))

children.value: iterations your training error must be zero. In practice it often makes sense to keep boosting even after you make no more mistakes on the training set.
